name: df-inv
params: setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2
body: |- wceq(cinv, cmpt(s0, ccat, cmpo(s1, s2, cfv(cbs, cv(s0)), cfv(cbs, cv(s0)), cin(co(cv(s1), cfv(csect, cv(s0)), cv(s2)), ccnv(co(cv(s2), cfv(csect, cv(s0)), cv(s1)))))))
bodyPretty: ⊢ Inv =(s0 ∈ Cat ↦(s1 ∈(Base ` s0), s2 ∈(Base ` s0)↦((s1[(Sect ` s0)]s2)⋂ `'(s2[(Sect ` s0)]s1))))
comment: The inverse relation in a category. Given arrows ` f : X --> Y ` and ` g : Y --> X ` , we say ` g Inv f ` , that is, ` g ` is an inverse of ` f ` , if ` g ` is a section of ` f ` and ` f ` is a section of ` g ` . Definition 3.8 of [Adamek] p. 28. (Contributed by FL, 22-Dec-2008.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 2-Jan-2017.)
